content.webTitle: New CSIRO chief Larry Marshall: focus on innovation needed to secure funding

fields.headline: New CSIRO chief Larry Marshall: focus on innovation needed to secure funding
fields.bodyText: The newly appointed chief executive of the CSIRO is hopeful he can convince the federal government that it is in the best interests of Australia to keep funding the organisation, which is still reeling from $111m in government funding cuts and facing 500 job losses. Technology entrepreneur Larry Marshall said his experience running start-up ventures through three US recessions meant he was “no stranger to adversity, difficult times and crises”. “The one thing that always comes from a crisis is that it turns into the catalyst for change and redirection, which generally leads to something great,” Marshall told ABC Radio National on Friday morning. “I’m actually somewhat hopeful that we will be able to convince the government thats it’s very much in the interest of the country to continue to fund CSIRO, and I don’t think it’s going to take very much convincing. “I think there is no one else capable in Australia, on a massive scale, [of conducting] research across so many areas that affect so many aspects of Australians’ lives.” To do that, he would have to focus on the innovation arm of the organisation, Marshall told the ABC. He said his background as a scientist, entrepreneur and venture capitalist uniquely positioned him to do that and meant he also appreciated the importance of basic, fundamental science. He would not step away from that core work in the process of trying to commercialise and monetise technology, he said. “I did things backwards, I fell in love with the technology first, which you should never do, and then I went out and tried to figure out what the most important problem was that we could solve with that technology,” he said. “If you’re a pure business person you would never do that, you always start with problem then try and find the technology to solve it. “In a way my history makes me uniquely qualified to help CSIRO take the wonderful innovations and science and make it meaningful and bring it to real-world products that affect the lives of every Australian and become an important part of Australian industry.” But he also acknowledged: “It’s not innovation until someone writes a cheque.” Marshall will replace geologist Dr Megan Clark, the CSIRO’s first female chief executive, when her term expires at the end of the year.
